briefdescription.para: We try to default to a different path style depending on the operating system.

detaileddescription.para: So this should detect whether we should use windows or unix paths

briefdescription.para: This is a list of separators used in different styles.

detaileddescription.para: Windows can read multiple separators, but it generally outputs just a backslash The output will always use the first character for the output

memberdef.argsstring: (char *buffer, size_t buffer_size, size_t position, const char *str, size_t length)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_output_sized

memberdef.argsstring: (char *buffer, size_t buffer_size, size_t position, const char *str)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_output

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *base, const char *path, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_get_absolute

briefdescription.para: Generates an absolute path based on a base.

detaileddescription.para: This function generates an absolute path based on a base path and another path It is guaranteed to return an absolute path If the second submitted path is absolute, it will override the base path The result will be written to a buffer, which might be truncated if the buffer is not large enough to hold the full path However, the truncated result will always be null-terminated The returned value is the amount of characters which the resulting path would take if it was not truncated (excluding the null-terminating character)

parameterdescription.para: The base path on which the relative path will be applied
The relative path which will be applied on the base path
The buffer where the result will be written to
The size of the result buffer

simplesect.para: Returns the total amount of characters of the new absolute path

memberdef.argsstring: (struct cwk_segment_joined *bsj, struct cwk_segment_joined *osj, bool absolute, bool *base_available, bool *other_available)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_skip_segments_until_diverge

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *base_directory, const char *path, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_get_relative

briefdescription.para: Generates a relative path based on a base.

detaileddescription.para: This function generates a relative path based on a base path and another path It determines how to get to the submitted path, starting from the base directory The result will be written to a buffer, which might be truncated if the buffer is not large enough to hold the full path However, the truncated result will always be null-terminated The returned value is the amount of characters which the resulting path would take if it was not truncated (excluding the null-terminating character)

parameterdescription.para: The base path from which the relative path will start
The target path where the relative path will point to
The buffer where the result will be written to
The size of the result buffer

simplesect.para: Returns the total amount of characters of the full path

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *path_a, const char *path_b, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_join

briefdescription.para: Joins two paths together.

detaileddescription.para: This function generates a new path by combining the two submitted paths It will remove double separators, and unlike cwk_path_get_absolute it permits the use of two relative paths to combine The result will be written to a buffer, which might be truncated if the buffer is not large enough to hold the full path However, the truncated result will always be null-terminated The returned value is the amount of characters which the resulting path would take if it was not truncated (excluding the null-terminating character)

parameterdescription.para: The first path which comes first
The second path which comes after the first
The buffer where the result will be written to
The size of the result buffer

simplesect.para: Returns the total amount of characters of the full, combined path

briefdescription.para: Joins multiple paths together.

detaileddescription.para: This function generates a new path by joining multiple paths together It will remove double separators, and unlike cwk_path_get_absolute it permits the use of multiple relative paths to combine The last path of the submitted string array must be set to NULL The result will be written to a buffer, which might be truncated if the buffer is not large enough to hold the full path However, the truncated result will always be null-terminated The returned value is the amount of characters which the resulting path would take if it was not truncated (excluding the null-terminating character)

parameterdescription.para: An array of paths which will be joined
The buffer where the result will be written to
The size of the result buffer

simplesect.para: Returns the total amount of characters of the full, combined path

briefdescription.para: Determines the root of a path.

detaileddescription.para: This function determines the root of a path by finding it's length The root always starts at the submitted path If the path has no root, the length will be set to zero

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The output of the root length

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *path, const char *new_root, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_change_root

briefdescription.para: Changes the root of a path.

detaileddescription.para: This function changes the root of a path It does not normalize the result The result will be written to a buffer, which might be truncated if the buffer is not large enough to hold the full path However, the truncated result will always be null-terminated The returned value is the amount of characters which the resulting path would take if it was not truncated (excluding the null-terminating character)

parameterdescription.para: The original path which will get a new root
The new root which will be placed in the path
The output buffer where the result is written to
The size of the output buffer where the result is written to

simplesect.para: Returns the total amount of characters of the new path

briefdescription.para: Determine whether the path is absolute or not.

detaileddescription.para: This function checks whether the path is an absolute path or not A path is considered to be absolute if the root ends with a separator

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be checked

simplesect.para: Returns true if the path is absolute or false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Determine whether the path is relative or not.

detaileddescription.para: This function checks whether the path is a relative path or not A path is considered to be relative if the root does not end with a separator

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be checked

simplesect.para: Returns true if the path is relative or false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Gets the basename of a file path.

detaileddescription.para: This function gets the basename of a file path A pointer to the beginning of the basename will be returned through the basename parameter This pointer will be positioned on the first letter after the separator The length of the file path will be returned through the length parameter The length will be set to zero and the basename to NULL if there is no basename available

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The output of the basename pointer
The output of the length of the basename

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *path, const char *new_basename, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_change_basename

briefdescription.para: Changes the basename of a file path.

detaileddescription.para: This function changes the basename of a file path This function will not write out more than the specified buffer can contain However, the generated string is always null-terminated - even if not the whole path is written out The function returns the total number of characters the complete buffer would have, even if it was not written out completely The path may be the same memory address as the buffer

parameterdescription.para: The original path which will be used for the modified path
The new basename which will replace the old one
The buffer where the changed path will be written to
The size of the result buffer where the changed path is written to

simplesect.para: Returns the size which the complete new path would have if it was not truncated

briefdescription.para: Gets the dirname of a file path.

detaileddescription.para: This function determines the dirname of a file path and returns the length up to which character is considered to be part of it If no dirname is found, the length will be set to zero The beginning of the dirname is always equal to the submitted path pointer

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The length of the dirname

briefdescription.para: Gets the extension of a file path.

detaileddescription.para: This function extracts the extension portion of a file path A pointer to the beginning of the extension will be returned through the extension parameter if an extension is found and true is returned This pointer will be positioned on the dot The length of the extension name will be returned through the length parameter If no extension is found both parameters won't be touched and false will be returned

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The output of the extension pointer
The output of the length of the extension

simplesect.para: Returns true if an extension is found or false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Determines whether the file path has an extension.

detaileddescription.para: This function determines whether the submitted file path has an extension This will evaluate to true if the last segment of the path contains a dot

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected

simplesect.para: Returns true if the path has an extension or false otherwise

memberdef.argsstring: (const char *path, const char *new_extension, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_change_extension

briefdescription.para: Changes the extension of a file path.

detaileddescription.para: This function changes the extension of a file name The function will append an extension if the basename does not have an extension, or use the extension as a basename if the path does not have a basename This function will not write out more than the specified buffer can contain However, the generated string is always null-terminated - even if not the whole path is written out The function returns the total number of characters the complete buffer would have, even if it was not written out completely The path may be the same memory address as the buffer

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be used to make the change
The extension which will be placed within the new path
The output buffer where the result will be written to
The size of the output buffer where the result will be written to

simplesect.para: Returns the total size which the output would have if it was not truncated

briefdescription.para: Creates a normalized version of the path.

detaileddescription.para: This function creates a normalized version of the path within the specified buffer This function will not write out more than the specified buffer can contain However, the generated string is always null-terminated - even if not the whole path is written out The function returns the total number of characters the complete buffer would have, even if it was not written out completely The path may be the same memory address as the buffer
The following will be true for the normalized path: 1) "../" will be resolved 2) "./" will be removed 3) double separators will be fixed with a single separator 4) separator suffixes will be removed

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be normalized
The buffer where the new path is written to
The size of the buffer

simplesect.para: The size which the complete normalized path has if it was not truncated

briefdescription.para: Finds common portions in two paths.

detaileddescription.para: This function finds common portions in two paths and returns the number characters from the beginning of the base path which are equal to the other path

parameterdescription.para: The base path which will be compared with the other path
The other path which will compared with the base path

simplesect.para: Returns the number of characters which are common in the base path

briefdescription.para: Gets the first segment of a path.

detaileddescription.para: This function finds the first segment of a path The position of the segment is set to the first character after the separator, and the length counts all characters until the next separator (excluding the separator)

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The segment which will be extracted

simplesect.para: Returns true if there is a segment or false if there is none

briefdescription.para: Gets the last segment of the path.

detaileddescription.para: This function gets the last segment of a path This function may return false if the path doesn't contain any segments, in which case the submitted segment parameter is not modified The position of the segment is set to the first character after the separator, and the length counts all characters until the end of the path (excluding the separator)

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected
The segment which will be extracted

simplesect.para: Returns true if there is a segment or false if there is none

briefdescription.para: Advances to the next segment.

detaileddescription.para: This function advances the current segment to the next segment If there are no more segments left, the submitted segment structure will stay unchanged and false is returned

parameterdescription.para: The current segment which will be advanced to the next one

simplesect.para: Returns true if another segment was found or false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Moves to the previous segment.

detaileddescription.para: This function moves the current segment to the previous segment If the current segment is the first one, the submitted segment structure will stay unchanged and false is returned

parameterdescription.para: The current segment which will be moved to the previous one

simplesect.para: Returns true if there is a segment before this one or false otherwise

briefdescription.para: Gets the type of the submitted path segment.

detaileddescription.para: This function inspects the contents of the segment and determines the type of it Currently, there are three types CWK_NORMAL, CWK_CURRENT and CWK_BACK A CWK_NORMAL segment is a normal folder or file entry A CWK_CURRENT is a "./" and a CWK_BACK a "../" segment

parameterdescription.para: The segment which will be inspected

simplesect.para: Returns the type of the segment

briefdescription.para: Checks whether the submitted pointer points to a separator.

detaileddescription.para: This function simply checks whether the submitted pointer points to a separator, which has to be null-terminated (but not necessarily after the separator) The function will return true if it is a separator, or false otherwise

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to a string

simplesect.para: Returns true if it is a separator, or false otherwise

memberdef.argsstring: (struct cwk_segment *segment, const char *value, char *buffer, size_t buffer_size)
memberdef.name: cwk_path_change_segment

briefdescription.para: Changes the content of a segment.

detaileddescription.para: This function overrides the content of a segment to the submitted value and outputs the whole new path to the submitted buffer The result might require less or more space than before if the new value length differs from the original length The output is truncated if the new path is larger than the submitted buffer size, but it is always null-terminated The source of the segment and the submitted buffer may be the same

parameterdescription.para: The segment which will be modifier
The new content of the segment
The buffer where the modified path will be written to
The size of the output buffer

simplesect.para: Returns the total size which would have been written if the output was not truncated

briefdescription.para: Guesses the path style.

detaileddescription.para: This function guesses the path style based on a submitted path-string The guessing will look at the root and the type of slashes contained in the path and return the style which is more likely used in the path

parameterdescription.para: The path which will be inspected

simplesect.para: Returns the style which is most likely used for the path

briefdescription.para: Configures which path style is used.

detaileddescription.para: This function configures which path style is used The following styles are currently supported
CWK_STYLE_WINDOWS: Use backslashes as a separator and volume for the root CWK_STYLE_UNIX: Use slashes as a separator and a slash for the root

parameterdescription.para: The style which will be used from now on

briefdescription.para: Gets the path style configuration.

detaileddescription.para: This function gets the style configuration which is currently used for the paths This configuration determines how paths are parsed and generated

simplesect.para: Returns the current path style configuration
